STARTER: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
text:
[Starter]: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
[Student]: Well you will be famous in the future then I think He spoke very seriously and his voice was sweet with pride as he listened to this note that shook so pleasantly in front of him as it went from mouth to ear without touching the keys on either hand when he had finished speaking at last over the sound of the keyhole above him and the latch opening under his cheek like an open door closing in upon him all through the long hallway of one of the halls where his own room stood and he fell asleep on the floor beside it crying bitterly that he would not move until morning broke and he could hardly take breath for another nap by which time he might be aroused from sleep again by some loud breathing noise outside the corner of the corridor
[Teacher]: . It was this noise that he could hear again, this time it was louder and closer and he felt it on his chest, his heart racing with fear as his hand reached out to grab something. I must tell you that I did not say all this is going on because it describes the whole story of how I met my best friend, he told me that I was going to be famous in the future so I must write this story as the most important story ever because I have written it because I do not want to leave the earth in the most insignificant way and I want my story to be read by as many people as possible. I wrote a story for my class assignment about a person who was going to be famous in the future. In order
[Student]: to get rid of his bad reputation and lose everything he possessed and now he has spent all his life working toward the end of his senior year since coming here but if any such thing happens to him we are obliged to treat it as righteous and righteously as we can and go back home together in peace Said Buddy Jim as they walked along silently in silence saying good night and nosing their footsteps in the darkness till they were tired and sleepy
[Teacher]: and walked further in a very slow pace toward the door. Buddy Jim said to me that I do not have to be afraid of anything because I am going to be famous in the future and his words echoed in my ears every day after that as I worked harder and harder to finish my school year and I felt that I too would be famous one day. I did not expect to be famous as Buddy Jim did but it was all the same that I was going to be famous one day. So I kept writing and writing and I never left my room for days and days after Buddy Jim left and I felt so happy when I was writing that I would cry at times and I would write that I was going to be famous one day. I even told
[Student]: myself that before my lesson hour came into being I should try to become really famous myself and the only thing that made it seem so much better than it seems to be there is is playing games just a little bit and it makes me feel sad sometimes cause Im old and I dont have much friends Then Buddy Jim began to dream of dreamshe dreamed about what Harry Potter did with the lantern in the closet of our big house and he didnt know why he wasnt coming home yet and if he does it means that he doesnt know that he isnt going to leave it to others I dont want to make that up said Billy Hickey in a disappointed tone as he heard these two verses in the
[Teacher]: song that he had bought from the boy in the market the boy who was sitting in a bench outside a store and he looked like the devil when he saw him. He listened to the song while he sat on the bench and he sang it to himself every day until his friends found out and they teased him and said they would help him to sing it in public and soon they would go up on the stage and sing that song and Billy Hickey would not be ashamed anymore and it would be a famous song and people would all be singing it and Billy Hickey would feel happy and proud and Billy Hickey would sing the song every day and that made him happy. The boy in the market also sat on the bench every day and he listened to the

STARTER: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
text:
[Starter]: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
[Student]: Do you remember anything about your father And he pointed to a little girl standing by the window with her pretty blue eyes looking down into the wistful light of the sunshiny evening sky that shone in the glory of his day when he sat there alone with his arms folded over him before him as if she were a fairy queen and told him about Mamma and how they had all wondered at each other for long months from beginning to end
[Teacher]: at the village of which he had heard so much before and never been to yet. He told him about the tiny church with its tiny spire that stood right in the middle of the village and about the people who lived in the village and the things they did and the things they wore and the stories they told and the laughter and the singing and the drums and the music and the dancing and the people and the things they did. He told him all about Mamma and how she had walked through the village in her white dress with her long black hair falling down her back like a river of night and how she had smiled at the villagers and how they had smiled back at her and how they had all felt happy and safe and warm with her in their
[Student]: homes or where they grew up until now
[Teacher]: and she was no more. He told him all about the tiny church and its tiny spire and the villagers who lived in it and the stories they told and the laughter and the singing and the drums and the music and the dancing that went on there and that they still did to this day, though the tiny spire was no longer there now, for it had been lost to the storm that had raged through the village long ago, and he told him all about the villagers who had lived and had died and had been born and had lived and had died again and that he had heard so much about them but never seen them before, but he was going to go see them and meet them and tell them all about Mamma and the tiny church
[Student]: because they thought it would be very nice to have the picturesque old picture painted beautifully in those pictures but still it seemed really funny to be living in such beautiful places only then
[Teacher]: to have the most wonderful and the most beautiful places lost to storms and what had it been that had really happened to the tiny church and why had it fallen down and what had happened to the villagers and why had they left the village and he had no idea because he had never been there before but he was going to go and find out. This was how he remembered him sitting there in the room, telling him all these stories and telling him about his village and his people and his past and his feelings and his thoughts and his stories and all the things he told him and all the stories and all the things he told him and all the stories and all the things he told him and all the stories and all the things he told him and all the stories

STARTER: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
text:
[Starter]: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
[Student]: Have they been there before He gave an indignant laugh and threw off his coat as if he was talking to himself with them all the time looking down at him with some interest in their sporting activity of life and action as well as for the prospects of a real gamey existence which would make an ideal football coach for young people like himself just entering into a big thinga chance for the big boys to fill ones own personal interestswhich were not very much to be had by the little schoolboys friends who loved to do itbut more importantly than being able to tell how good a way is to learn what we are doing without having made so many mistakes when discussing the advantages of our school education to us
[Teacher]: and not just to the people who are already in charge of it and what would happen to us if we did not make the most of it and what we will do when we finish our school education and how to get ahead in the world of business to all these questions which would be asked to him by some of the boys and he just shook his head and said that he was not sure and did not know how to answer them but he was very sure of one thing that he wanted to make the most of it and that he wanted to make the most of his education and he just smiled as he said that he would rather be a fish out of water than a chicken who had never really felt the water and this was an expression he would often use when

STARTER: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
text:
[Starter]: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
[Student]: Do they live together or die when we are away from home asked Betty curiously as she made her curtsy to make sure there was no one in the house who did not know how many things Betty knew of all that happened at school except herself
[Teacher]: . The girl and the cat were sitting at the same table in the school canteen, the girl being an oddity to most of the school because of her extremely advanced knowledge.  The girl was known as the "Brainy Betty" and the cat was the "Brainy Cat" of the class.  Betty's eyes gleamed with interest as she listened to the girl's answers to her questions.  She had two cats, Muffin and Misty.  Betty had them since she was five years old.  Betty liked most things about her cats, but she especially liked that they were very affectionate.  Muffin and Misty lived together in the same house as Betty.  Betty was
[Student]: a kind little soul who loved games and so did other girls besides themselvesbest friends among boys and girls whose friendship came to a close when she was only fourteen years older than she would be if possible in life instead of taking part in some other thing or anything else which would take place during summer when it is vacation time for study hours
[Teacher]: . Betty's parents were very kind to her and her sisters.  They taught her and her sisters how to drive a car.  Betty's best friend was a girl named Lucy who was also known as the "Brainy Lucy" of their school.  Lucy was very smart and loved to solve puzzles and play games.  Betty loved Lucy dearly.  She would often go to her house to play games and do homework.  Lucy's family lived close to Betty's family.  Lucy's parents were very kind to her and her brother, and Lucy liked playing with her brother very much.  The girl and the cat were talking about how they were going to spend their summer vacation.  The girl was thinking of spending her summer at a
[Student]: farmhouse where she could get food enough to eat whenever anybody wished to buy vegetables she wanted and she wondered why people should call in that way because it was such a different feeling from what had come over her after winter without saying good morning to anyone about it now and then
[Teacher]: .  She was going to a farm that belonged to a very rich man who lived in the city.  The girl and the cat would be living in the house with the rich man and his family and they would have to follow the rules of the farm.  They were going to have to learn to ride horses and to cook food that the rich man wanted them to cook.  The girl was not very happy about it because she had to go away from her home and from her best friend.  She was going to have to live in a different house and be with people who were very rich.  The girl was worried about what she would do when she was back home and how she would do without her best friend.  The girl and

text:
[Starter]: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
[Student]: Where are they now said Julia in surprise and pleasure at hearing this reply from her husbands lips while he was speaking to the children who were outside waiting for him to go out to look after his family when he should be back at school or college or perhaps study some other language of his own that he might not know a word of all those others who could learn it well if their mother did so yet she wondered how far away she would take him on one good day as soon as he knew of possible danger from the little ones for no one else understood how anxious Julia was to show up and leave the schoolhouse if Miss South Graham hadnt asked permission to see him again or to visit his fathers house for more than fifteen minutes
[Teacher]: and Julia was glad that she wasnt going to have to face those little terrors on her way home.   However, this passage doesn't appear to be a typical example of a passage where someone discusses their pets. The passage seems to be a stream-of-consciousness passage that reveals the thoughts and feelings of the character Julia as she overhears her husband speaking to the children. The passage is more focused on Julia's inner thoughts and feelings than on a discussion about pets. Or perhaps it's because of the other passages we have read and that Julia is the daughter of Miss South Graham and that we have seen Julia as a little

[Teacher]: , what is Julia's situation? Brenda replies "Julia is anxious because of her husbands interest in the children. She is also anxious about his desire to study languages and what this may mean for the family.  She is concerned about the time he spends away from home and the effect this may have on the children.  She is anxious to see him return home and is anxious to meet him when he does.  She is worried about his relationship with the children and whether he is spending enough time with them.  She is worried about her own role in the family and how she is perceived by the children and her husband.  She is also anxious about the future and how it may affect her family.  She is anxious about her husband's

text:

[Student]: I mean it is very good for everyone because we have a home where people are going to get hungry all their lives And he smiled happily and said in an undertoneYesterday I was sitting up on my bed with mother last night The cook looked surprised as she said this under her breath Im very glad of your company but there seemed no reason why she should not go away that night just after supper time while they were preparing something new to eat and then take a nap again until evening time when the morning had come to take them back again from school and then make camp time for dinner She laughed softly over what could be called The Cookery Club So the girls went back to school together and soon came back bringing
[Teacher]: what they had made for supper that night She said it was a good thing for them to know how to make many things themselves so they could take care of their families And she then began to give some advice to the girl who was most afraid of cooking She said to her Its good for a girl to be able to cook and she said to her Im not afraid of cooking I can cook and she said to her I wish you could learn how to make a cake She said to her I wish I could but my mother says I am not good at making cakes so I said to her But you can still learn and she said yes and she taught me and then she taught the rest of us and so the cook said to her I am glad of your company

[Teacher]: and they dont want anything nice about doing right But I will say to them what I have said to you I will never be afraid of doing something for the sake of all people and for the sake of my own peace of mind and to make it easy for them to do the same because I have seen that many people are glad to do good and they only wait for you to start but that is not the way I will do things with my friends and my family and my teacher and the world but I will try to do good and to make others do the same and then I will have a good time And that is the way the world ought to be I think that every one ought to be good to each other and do good deeds and to make the
[Student]: world believe that nothing really has any place to live In fact I do wonder where our hearts will lead To what makes us such a fool People who we cannot help anyway But it is so good to see us alive again You wont forget it all because your mother does not appreciate life itself so you will remember It is good to hear us laugh and you may trust us to be good to ourselves I am sure you will understand now I am sure you will be pleased too With that thought you have heard of folks coming through the woods And you will certainly be proud That everybody deserves to be a friend indeed and be a friend and always will be a friend and always will be a friend and always will be a friend and always will be a friend and always will

This passage is a conversation between a young girl and her cook, who is teaching her and her friends various skills such as cooking, manners, and good behavior. The girl is eager to learn and wants to be a good person and make others happy. She is impressed by the cook's patience and kindness, and wants to follow her example. The passage is written in a simple and clear style, with short sentences and a conversational tone. It conveys a positive message about the importance of kindness, cooperation, and doing good deeds. The passage also highlights the relationship between the girl and her cook, who is shown to be a wise and compassionate mentor. The cook's advice

(There is a bit of editing to make it a short version) Here is the short version: It's Thanksgiving, and the young woman is feeling happy, surrounded by her family in their home. Her grandmother was telling stories about how the family used to travel long distances to visit their relatives, and how they would pass through cherry orchards filled with apple blossoms. As she listened to her grandmother's stories, the young woman remembered all the special traditions and funny stories from past Thanksgivings. One time, her brother had accidentally set off the fire alarm while trying
[Student]: to get out of his shell and had fallen back over a stone wall in order to kill him with his axe and knife
[Teacher]: . Another time, her brother had gotten his head stuck in a turkey drum. The young woman laughed at the memory of her brother's silly antics. She felt grateful to be surrounded by her loving family and to have such happy memories of past Thanksgivings.
